{{Tone|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Heather Dewey-Hagborg |image=DNA Spoofing - 2.jpg |caption=Heather Dewey-Hagborg (photo from her 2013 project ''DNA Spoofing'') | birth_date = June 4, 1982 | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | residence = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Information artist | alma_mater = New York University | notable works = Stranger Visions | website = http://deweyhagborg.com | module = {{Listen |embed=yes| filename = Dewey-Hagborg.ogg| title = Heather Dewey-Hagborg Voice| type = speech| description = recorded in August 2014}} }}
'''Heather Dewey-Hagborg''' (born June 4, 1982, [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]) is an information artist and [[Do-it-yourself biology|bio-hacker]].<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> She is most noted for her project [[#Stranger Visions|''Stranger Visions'']]: a series of portraits created from [[DNA]] she recovered from discarded items, such as hair, cigarettes and chewing gum while living in [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> She sequenced the DNA at the Brooklyn open [[biotechnology]] laboratory, [[Genspace]].<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Wilson Center"/> From the extracted DNA, she determined gender, ethnicity and other factors and then used face-generating software and a [[3D printer]] to create a speculative, algorithmically determined 3D portrait. While critical of technology and surveillance, her work has been found disturbing by some critics.<ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/tech/innovation/dna-face-sculptures/ Natalie Angley, "Artist creates faces from DNA left in public"], CNN.com, September 4, 2013.</ref>
==Education== [[File:Spurious Memories.jpg|thumb|''Spurious Memories'' (2007)]] Dewey-Hagborg is an information and bio artist whose works explore the intersection between art and science.<ref name="Colanduno, D.">{{cite web|last1=Colanduno|first1=Derek|authorlink=Derek Colanduno|title=Pieces of You #223|url=http://www.skepticality.com/piecesofyou|website=Skepticality|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=December 31, 2013}}</ref> As a student in the Information Arts program at [[Bennington College]],<ref name="Wilkinson, A.">{{cite journal|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Alec|title=Mask Crusader|journal=New Yorker|date=July 1, 2013|volume=89|issue=19|pages=22–23|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/07/01/mask-crusader|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref> she participated in computer science classes, which laid the groundwork for the science-based artwork she would later envision using [[algorithms]], [[electronics]], and [[computer programming]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She earned a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in 2003.
Dewey-Hagborg continued refining her work as an artist and computer programmer, studying [[artificial intelligence]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> while obtaining a Master of Professional Studies (M.P.S.) in Interactive Telecommunications from [[New York University]] (NYU)<ref name="Schwendener1">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|publisher=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> in 2007. It was here she curated a robotic performance art show called ''Robots on the March!'' in March 2005, and exhibited a piece called ''Lighter than Air: an experiment in constructing an autonomous flying robot''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photosynthesis and Experiments in Sustainable Robotics|url=http://www.atasite.org/calendar/archive/index-24133.html|website=Artists' Television Access|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=March 25 – April 30, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Lighter Than Air|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJmu-AzrXH4|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref>
As a final project at NYU, Dewey-Hagborg explored the question "Can computers be creative?" in an exhibit she called Spurious Memories. She developed an autonomous face categorizing and generating software program which recognized facial components, made comparisons and adjustments, and produced unique representations of the human face through mass exposure to facial images.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Spurious Memories|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1elpx1rz_R0|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=April 16, 2011}}</ref>
After graduating from NYU, she became a doctoral candidate in electronics arts at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]]<ref name="Dawsey, J">{{cite news|last1=Dawsey|first1=Josh|title=Art emerges from DNA left behind|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324281004578352473833386586|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|issue=Eastern Edition|date=March 11, 2013|page=A19}}</ref><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A.">{{cite web|last1=Squires|first1=Acacia|title=Litterbugs beware: turning found DNA into portraits|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/12/183363361/litterbugs-beware-turning-found-dna-into-portraits|website=NPR|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rodrigo, N.">{{cite web|last1=Rodrigo|first1=Nandi|title=Faces in the Crowd, Printed in 3-D|url=http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/faces-in-the-crowd-printed-in-3-d/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|website=The New York Times Blog|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Herper, M.">{{cite news|last1=Herper|first1=Matthew|title=Artist Creates Portraits from People's DNA. Scientists Say 'That's Impossible'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2013/05/31/turning-found-dna-into-portraits-what-an-imagination|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=Forbes|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> and is expected to graduate in 2016.
Dewey-Hagborg has worked as a teaching assistant at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute,<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=CV|url=http://www.deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|website=deweyhagborg|accessdate=August 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827212543/http://deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|archivedate=August 27, 2014|df=}}</ref> an adjunct professor at NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program,<ref>{{cite web|title=Interactive Telecommunication|website=Tisch School of the Arts|publisher=New York University|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=152|year=2011–2013}}</ref> and an adjunct professor at NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/><ref name="MoMa PS1"/>
As of August 2014, Dewey-Hagborg resides in [[Chicago, Illinois]], teaching art and technology studies at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Art and Technology Studies: Faculty|url=http://www.saic.edu/profiles/faculty/heatherdewey-hagborg|website=School of the Art Institute of Chicago|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> As an educator her areas of interest include art and technology, multimedia, digital photography, research-based art and programming, and computer science.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/>
==Selected projects== ===Totem=== [[File:Heather Dewey-Hagborg Totem.jpg|thumb|''Totem'' (2010)]] Dewey-Hagborg's ''Totem'' (2010) was a site-specific multimedia sculpture characterizing her earlier work. ''Totem'', an idol, was designed to explore the implications of language and artificial intelligence using [[machine learning]] technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Guide July thru December 2011|url=http://issuu.com/groundsforsculpture/docs/summerfall2011|website=ISSUU.com|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=15}}</ref> Exploiting audio surveillance techniques to eavesdrop on and record conversations at the installation site, Dewey-Hagborg wrote algorithms to then isolate word sequences and grammatical structures into commonly used units. Influenced by [[Hebbian theory]], she programmed the sculpture's computer to generate speech based on the most frequently occurring language structures in any given recording period. Over time, the least frequently elicited words or units would fade or be dropped from the sculpture's spoken vocabulary. The remaining units, stored in the sculpture's memory, were then spoken at random intervals.<ref name=Totem/>
The piece also reflected the writings of psychologist [[Julian Jaynes]]. According to Dewey-Hagborg, Jaynes theorized that an early form of human consciousness evolved as a result of hallucinated speech experienced by the Mari civilization of the [[Euphrates]]. The ancient people interpreted water trickling through a goddess statue as whispers or vocalizations from the goddess herself.<ref name=Totem/> Dewey-Hagborg saw a parallel between the "mystical and authoritative power of language in the ancient world and the force of power of technology today"<ref name="Totem">{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Totem|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GsTu3Iv1408|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=June 28, 2010}}</ref> and, with this piece, sought to explore how technology is used to shape public opinion and behavior.
Martha Schwendener, of ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote that ''Totem'' showed promise, but, because of audio difficulties and its fragmented, randomly generated speech, the piece "failed to connect human speech, meaning, and technology in a profound fashion."<ref name="Schwendener, M.">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/nyregion/at-grounds-for-sculpture-works-by-james-surls-and-daniel-henderson-review.html?_r=0|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
===''Stranger Visions''=== [[File:Stranger Visions-1.jpg|left|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' Portraits (2012)]] ''Stranger Visions'' (2012–2014) is a science-based, artistic exploration using DNA as a starting point for Dewey-Hagborg's lifelike, computer generated 3-D portraits.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Jenkins, M.">{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Mark|title=A 'Cyber' exhibit as timely as the news|work=Washington Post|date=September 18, 2013|page=E18}}</ref><ref name="Krulwich, R.">{{cite web|last1=Krulwich|first1=Robert|title=Artist plays detective: Can I reconstruct a face from a piece of hair?|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/2013/06/28/196307915/artist-plays-detective-can-i-reconstruct-a-face-from-a-piece-of-hair|website=NPR|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite news|title=Trafics optiques a l'heure numerique: a Creteil, l'exposition "Micro Macro" interroge notre perception du reel"|work=Le Monde|date=April 6, 2014}}</ref>
She began this project questioning how much information could be understood about a person using genetic detritus left behind by strangers in [[New York City]].<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Brodwin, E.">{{cite journal|last1=Brodwin|first1=Erin|title=New Generation of Bio-Hackers make DNA misbehave|journal=Newsweek Global|date=July 4, 2014|volume=162|issue=26|pages=1–7|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/07/04/new-generation-bio-hackers-make-dna-misbehave-256322.html|accessdate=August 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> "I was really struck by this idea that the very things that make us human – hair, skin, saliva, and fingernails – become a real liability for us as we constantly shed them in public. Anyone could come along and mine them for information."<ref name="Wang, L."/> She hoped, by producing realistic sculptures of anonymous people using clues from their DNA, to spark a debate about the use or the potential misuse of DNA profiling, privacy, and genetic surveillance.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wilson Center">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions: The DNA You Leave Behind|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/stranger-visions-the-dna-you-leave-behind|website=Wilson Center|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=June 3, 2013}}</ref><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art">{{cite journal|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg Stranger Visions|journal=C: International Contemporary Art|date=Winter 2014|volume=120|page=57}}</ref><ref name=Passarello>{{cite news|last1=Passarello|first1=D|title=Dna smarriti, una seconda vita che si fa opera d'arte|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|date=March 17, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Stranger Visions-6.jpg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 2" based on the DNA sample from a cigarette butt collected on Myrtle Avenue in New York City, N.Y.<ref name="Gambino, M.">{{cite web|last1=Gambino|first1=Megan|title=Creepy or Cool? Portraits Derived From the DNA in Hair and Gum Found in Public Places|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/creepy-or-cool-portraits-derived-from-the-dna-in-hair-and-gum-found-in-public-places-50266864/?no-ist|website=Smithsonian|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=May 3, 2013}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-4.jpg|thumb|Collection site for DNA Samples; Corner of Wilson Avenue and Stanhope Street in [[Bushwick, New York|Bushwick, Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-2.jpg|thumb|Gum collected, which, when analyzed by Dewey-Hagborg, revealed a male of Native American and South American descent with brown eyes.<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] As part of her research for ''Stranger Visions'', Dewey-Hagborg took a three-week crash-course<ref name="Wang, L."/> in biotechnology at Genspace, a non-profit, community-based biotechnology laboratory in New York. She was astonished to learn how much an amateur biologist could learn about someone.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L.">{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Linda|title=Guarding Our DNA: Art project exposes the vulnerability of the genetic material we unintentionally leave behind|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=June 24, 2013|volume=91|issue=25|page=33}}</ref><ref name="Pauwels, E.">{{cite news|last1=Pauwels|first1=Eleanore|title=Leave me your DNA ... and I'll 3-D print your face|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/01/dna-art-recreate-faces|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=The Guardian|date=June 1, 2013}}</ref>
She began the process of extracting DNA from the samples she collected. The extraction involves treating a hair sample, for example, with a gel that dissolves the hair, and a primer specifically developed to help locate characteristics like eye color or gender along the [[genome]].<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B.">{{cite news|last1=Gruber|first1=Ben|title=Artist stirs privacy debate with portraits from DNA|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2013/07/02/artist-stirs-privacy-debate-with-portrai?videoId=243713123|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=Reuters|date=July 2, 2013}}</ref> Dewey-Hagborg might repeat this process up to 40 times,<ref name="Andersen, K."/> looking for genetic variants influencing traits like eye color, hair color, and racial ancestry, in order to complete a portrait.<ref name="Aldous, P.">{{cite news|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Artwork highlights legal debate over 'abandoned' DNA|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23677-artworks-highlight-legal-debate-over-abandoned-dna.html#.U-N6YUi9g7A|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=New Scientist|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Once the DNA strands are extracted from the samples, Dewey-Hagborg then amplifies, or copies, specific regions of the genome, using a technique called [[Polymerase Chain Reaction]], or PCR, a process advanced by [[Kary Mullis]], a winner of the [[Nobel Prize]] in Chemistry (1993).<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/> These amplified regions of the genome make it possible to identifying [[single nucleotide polymorphisms]], or SNPs (pronounced "snips"),<ref name=Passarello/> which contain variables in the base pairs that give clues to a person's individual genetic make up (e.g., whether or not a person's eyes might be blue, brown or green). These results are then sent for analysis to a company for sequencing. Dewey-Hagborg used [[23andMe]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/> a DNA analysis service, for ''Stranger Visions''. [[File:Dna-SNP.svg|left|thumb|Illustration of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs)]] [[File:Stranger Visions-5.jpeg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 3" <ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Portraits|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141003124410/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|archivedate=October 3, 2014|df=}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-3.jpg|thumb|Sample collected for ''Stranger Visions'' on Myrtle Avenue, [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Samples|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013095339/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|archivedate=October 13, 2014|df=}}</ref>]]
The genetic blueprint<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B."/> she receives in return is a text file full of coded information identifying the unique positioning of the 4 [[nucleobase]]s [[adenine]], [[thymine]], [[cytosine]], and [[guanine]], or ATC and G, that make up the sections of the genome she is interested in.<ref name="Squires, A."/> This data is then entered into a customized computer program she wrote.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/> The program interprets the code and provides her with a list of traits, including propensity for obesity, eye color, hair color, hair curl, skin tone, freckles, and gender.<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> She then takes these traits, as many as 50, and enters them into a face-generating program to configure the 3-D portraits.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L."/> Her previous experience with facial recognition algorithms gave her the ability to repurpose an existing [[facial recognition system|facial recognition program]], from [[Basel]], Switzerland.<ref name="Walters, H.">{{cite web|last1=Walters|first1=Helen|title=A Portrait from a Single Hair: The Work of Heather-Dewey Hagborg|url=http://ideas.ted.com/2013/06/20/generating-a-sculpture-from-a-hair-the-work-of-heather-dewey-hagborg/|website=Ideas.Ted.Com|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 20, 2013}}</ref> She reworked the program to generate faces instead of just recognizing facial features.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> The resulting model changes facial dimensions (e.g., width of the nose and mouth) and characteristics with the genetic information it receives. Before making the final 3-D print,<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg generates several different versions of the face, finally choosing the one she finds most aesthetically pleasing.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K.">{{cite web|last1=Andersen|first1=Kurt|title=Making Portraits out of DNA|url=http://www.studio360.org/story/267842-making-portraits-out-of-dna|website=Studio 360|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=February 8, 2013}}</ref>
Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's ''Stranger Visions'' question whether or not the work crosses ethical and legal boundaries.<ref name="Aldous, Peter">{{cite journal|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Who's looking through your discarded DNA?|journal=New Scientist|date=2013-06-15|volume=281|issue=2921|page=12}}</ref> They make a distinction between an artist's right to express societal concerns through artwork and the act of collecting personal, genetic information without informed consent.<ref name="Gruber, B."/> The fact that DNA samples are regularly "left behind" or abandoned does not mean those people have relinquished their interest in how that information is used.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name=Passarello/>
Some laws, like that of the [[Human Tissue Act of 2004]] in the United Kingdom, prohibit private individuals from collecting biological samples for DNA analysis.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> What laws that exist to regulate the collection and use of DNA samples in the United States are not consistent among the states and rarely address the private sector.<ref name="Wilson Center"/> Only some states, like New York, outlaw most DNA testing without written consent.<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> Others worry about the misuse of the information, fearing discrimination based on existing medical or mental health issues or a predisposition for disease-related illnesses or "unreasonable" searches of DNA evidence by law enforcement.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/><ref name=Passarello/><ref name="Andersen, K."/><ref name="Enserink, M.">{{cite journal|last1=Enserink|first1=Martin|title=Emerging Forensics Field May Hit Legal and Ethical Obstacles|journal=Science|date=February 18, 2011|volume=331|doi=10.1126/science.331.6019.840|pages=840|pmid=21330505}}<!--|accessdate=August 7, 2014--></ref> One scientist and one gallery, according to Dewey-Hagborg, turned down her proposal fearing the project would "cause a fright" among people.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/>
Other critics focus on the growing do-it-yourself or [[Do-it-yourself biology|biohacking]] movement. Supporters like Genspace's Ellen Jorgensen claim projects like ''Stranger Visions'' engage the public and make the new technology more accessible.<ref name="Krulwich, R."/> Detractors fear unintended or unexpected consequences from unregulated experiments conducted by D.I.Y. amateur biologists developed in non-traditional laboratory settings.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
Still others, including Daniel MacArthur, an assistant professor at [[Harvard Medical School]], [[John D. Hawks]], an anthropologist at the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]], Michelle N. Meyer, an academic fellow at the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology & Bioethics at Harvard Medical School, and [[Arthur Caplan]], PhD, Director of the Division of Medical Ethics, N.Y.U., report that the technological capability to construct an accurate likeness of a human face based on DNA evidence is not currently available.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
Although it is possible to identify certain genetic markers linked to facial structures, scientists have yet to isolate all the genes and their variations needed to produce an accurate likeness with a computer simulation.<ref name=Passarello/> Meyer, who analyzed the data from Dewey-Hagborg's website concludes:
<blockquote>So far as I can tell, she's working with sex; ancestral groups that are usually very broad, and in any event only reflects half of the individual's DNA (from which she presumably guesses hair color and texture and bone structure); and a decent guess at eye color. There are hundreds of thousands (at least) of people who would fit these descriptions even if each of her phenotype predictions were accurate, and in many cases, one or more of the predictions are probably going to be wrong.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name=Passarello/></blockquote>
The environment, the probabilistic nature of interpreting the DNA data collected, and limitations of computer technology all influence the outcome.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She likens her work to that of a sketch artist.<ref name="Squires, A."/> At most, her portraits bear only a vague, family resemblance to the people whose genetic information was used as a foundation for the portraits.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
===''A Becoming Resemblance''=== In the summer of 2017 Dewey-Hagborg's collaborative exhibition with transgender activist [[Chelsea E. Manning]] opened at Fridman Gallery. The exhibition was an iteration of the artist's successful and controversial ''Stranger Visions'' project.<ref name="Kobler, J.">{{cite news|last1=Kobler|first1=Jason|title=Don't Give Your DNA to Giant Genetic Databases|work=Vice|date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In the case of ''A Becoming Resemblance'', Dewey-Hagborg created a series titled ''Radical Love'', 30 3-D printed portraits of Manning, based on cheek swabs and hair clippings that Manning sent her while incarcerated for leaking classified information to WikiLeaks. While all 30 portraits were based on Manning's DNA, their variances in skin color and features presents the malleability of DNA data. The installation demonstrated how much the human genome is up for interpretation once condensed and subjectively interpreted. "<ref name="Nevins, J.">{{cite news|last1=Nevins|first1=Jake|title=A Becoming Resemblance: artist creates portraits using Chelsea Manning's DNA.|work=The Guardian|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref> ''A Becoming Resemblance'' has since traveled to numerous institutions for exhibition, including The Transmedial in Berlin<ref name="Taylor, A.">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Alan|title=Photos of the Week: Super Blue Blood Moon, Starry Night, Stratofortress|work=The Atlantic|date=May 8, 2018}}</ref> ,Fridman Gallery,<ref>https://deweyhagborg.com/bio/</ref> MU Art Space in the Netherlands,<ref>http://www.mu.nl/en/exhibitions/heather-dewey-hagborg-genomic-intimacy</ref> and the 2018 Seattle Art Fair.<ref>https://seattleartfair.com/Projects-Talks/2018/Heather-Dewey-Hagborg-and-Chelsea-E-Manning-Probab.aspx</ref>
===Delaware=== [[File:Invisible-3.tif|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] In 2013, Dewey-Hagborg was contacted by an assistant medical examiner in Delaware,<ref name="Dawsey, J"/> as a result of her work with ''Stranger Visions''. The project involved developing a portrait of an unidentified woman whose case has remained unsolved for 20 years. She agreed to be an adviser to assist with the case.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> Though the resulting portrait based on the unidentified woman's DNA could only be as accurate as existing technology allowed, leaving room for speculation, Dewey-Hagborg viewed working on the case as the only potential use for this type of face-generating technology.<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Herper, M."/> "If you can add anything at all to her description, if you can increase the possibility her loved ones may find her even one little bit I think it's worth it."<ref name="Herper, M."/> Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's involvement in the Delaware case express concern for what they call "D.I.Y. forensic science" and question the role of civilians in state investigations.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
===''Invisible''=== [[File:Invisible-1.jpg|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] Dewey-Hagborg's work with ''Stranger Visions'' and interest in issues surrounding genetic surveillance lead to the development of two products whose purpose is to eliminate DNA traces. The first, ''Erase'', is a bleaching spray that cleans surfaces (e.g., cups, silverware) of DNA evidence. The second, ''Replace'', is a spray consisting of a blend of genes designed to introduce foreign DNA evidence to the surface, therefore masking any of the original DNA remaining in that area.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg views these as a "citizens' defense against the looming DNA surveillance state."<ref name="Hartnett, K.">{{cite news|last1=Hartnett|first1=Kevin|title=How to cover your DNA trail|work=Boston Globe|date=May 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Additional exhibitions and events== Dewey-Hagborg's work has been exhibited at The Monitor Digital Festival in [[Guadalajara]], Mexico,<ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> [[MoMA PS1|PS1 MoMA, Long Island City, New York]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> the [[New York Public Library]] in New York City, the [[Science Gallery]] at [[Trinity College Dublin|Trinity College Dublin, Ireland]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Science Gallery, Dublin">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Sculpture, 2013: Heather Dewey-Hagborg|url=https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/growyourown/strangervisions|website=Science Gallery|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> the [[University of Technology|UTS Gallery]] in [[Sydney, Australia]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> the [[Jaaga|Jaaga Art and Technology Center]] in [[Bangalore|Bangalore, India]], the [[Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen|Museum Boijmans]] in [[Rotterdam, Netherlands]], and the [[Ars Electronica Center]] in [[Linz, Austria]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/>
Dewey-Hagborg has also produced the following selected works: *''Trace Recordings: Surveillance and Identity in the 21st Century'' at the UTS Gallery, Ultimo NSW, Australia<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Frost, A.">{{cite news|last1=Frost|first1=Andrew|title=Artists use surveillance technology to explore extent we are monitored|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/nov/18/trace-recordings-surveillance-identity-review|accessdate=August 14, 2014|work=The Guardian|issue=Sunday|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref> *''Cyber In Securities'', Pepco Edison Place Gallery, Washington, D.C.<ref name="Jenkins, M."/> *''Plugged In: Interactive Art in Electronic Media'', [[Grounds for Sculpture]], Domestic Arts Building, [[Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey]].<ref name="Schwendener, M."/> *''DNA and Dust'' (with Paul Hazelton), QF Gallery, [[East Hampton, New York]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Art Round Up of the Week|url=http://hamptonsarthub.com/2013/07/19/art-round-up-week-of-07-19-13|accessdate=August 14, 2014|work=Hamptons Art Hub|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref> *''Unlanguage'' (with Adriana Varella), computer interactive installation, the Poland Mediations Bienniale, Zamek Castle, Poland.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> *''Open Circuit'', [[MoMA PS1|PS1 MoMA, Long Island City, New York]].<ref name="MoMa PS1">{{cite web|title=Saturday Sessions: Hosted by Mattew Radune, Heather Dewey-Hagborg, and Thomas Dexter Featuring Open Circuit|url=http://momaps1.org/calendar/view/270|website=MoMa PS1|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=January 29, 2011}}</ref> *''Jaaga Dhvani'', sound art, Bangalore, India<ref>{{cite web|title=Jaaga Dhvani: Space Voice|url=http://eyebeam.org/feeds/heather-dewey-hagborg/jaaga-dhvani-space-voice?page=2|website=Eyebeam|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=July 1, 2011}}</ref> *''A Becoming Resemblance'' (with [[Chelsea Manning]]), Fridman Gallery, [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=A Becoming Resemblance: artist creates portraits using Chelsea Manning's DNA |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/aug/03/chelsea-manning-hair-clippings-artist-portraits-dna|accessdate=August 3, 2017|work=The Guardian|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref>
==Selected grants and awards== *2016 [[Creative Capital]] Award<ref>{{cite web|title=Announcing the 2016 Creative Capital Awardees: $4,370,000 Committed to 46 Diverse Projects|url=https://www.creative-capital.org/news_items/view/561|website=Creative Capital|accessdate=October 5, 2017}}</ref> *2013 VIDA 15.0 Art and Artificial Life International Awards, special mention<ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions: Heather Dewey-Hagborg (USA)|url=http://vida.fundaciontelefonica.com/en/projects/vida-15|website=Telefonica Fundacion|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> *2012 Artist's Residency and Jerome Foundation Grant, [[Art International Radio|Clocktower Gallery]], Manhattan, N.Y.<ref name="Clockwork Tower">{{cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg, Stranger Visions|url=http://clocktower.org/residency/heather-dewey-hagborg-stranger-visions|website=Clockwork Tower|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=January 2, 2013}}</ref> *2012 Residency at Eyebeam<ref>{{Cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg {{!}} eyebeam.org|url=http://eyebeam.org/people/heather-dewey-hagborg|website=eyebeam.org|accessdate=2016-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg Uses DNA To Reconstruct Your Identity for Art|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/artist-heather-dewey-hagborg-uses-dna-surveillance-to-swipe-your-genetic-identity-for-art|website=Motherboard|accessdate=2016-02-01}}</ref> *2008 Artist's Residency and Grant, Sculpture Space, [[Utica, New York]].<ref name="Sculpture Space">{{cite web|title=Alumni Artists|url=http://www.sculpturespace.org/alumni-artists|website=Sculpture Space|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref>

{{for|the Danish university|IT University of Copenhagen}} '''IT University''' is a joint department between [[Chalmers University of Technology]] and [[University of Gothenburg|the University of Gothenburg]] in [[Sweden]]. This joint venture offers a great scope for cooperation between researchers with different areas of expertise and academic specialties within the field of [[information technology]].
The programmes offered are based on advanced research and are in a constant state of development. IT University was established in the autumn of 2001. Today it offers programs at both Bachelor's and Master's level, mostly with a focus on applied information technology.
== Programs in English == * [[C:Art:Media Master Program]] * Intelligent Systems Design * Master's in Software Engineering and Management * Software Engineering and Management International * MSc in Applied Data Science
==External links== * [http://www.ituniv.se IT University website]

'''Imprelis''' is a selective herbicide created by [[DuPont]]. The active ingredient is [[aminocyclopyrachlor]], a synthetic [[auxin]].<ref>Product label: http://www2.dupont.com/Professional_Products/en_US/assets/downloads/pdfs/H65717.pdf</ref><ref>MSDS: http://msds.dupont.com/msds/pdfs/EN/PEN_09004a358053f153.pdf</ref>
Imprelis was registered with the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]<ref>EPA site http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/chemical/pesticide-registrations/aminocyclopyrachlor.html</ref> for sale in October 2010.<ref>http://www.ksl.com/?nid=153&sid=16681845</ref> Sale of Imprelis was voluntarily suspended<ref>http://www.imprelis-facts.com/</ref> a week before the EPA required sales stopped.<ref>EPA site http://www.epa.gov/compliance/resources/cases/civil/fifra/dupontimprelis.html</ref><ref>http://www.ksl.com/?nid=153&sid=16681845</ref> DuPont acknowledged it was killing or damaging evergreen trees, including [[white pine]] and [[Norway spruce]].<ref name="DFP">Detroit Free Press, May 21, 2012, page A1</ref> DuPont allegedly knew Imprelis would damage evergreens before seeking EPA approval.<ref>Detroit Free Press, Aug 12, 2011, page A1</ref>
DuPont offered to compensate customers whose trees were affected. They asked that a claim be submitted, and said that they would send a claim resolution agreement, which would specify the amount DuPont would pay to settle the claim. By late May 2012, the end of the planting season, many tree owners had not heard from DuPont. Other tree owners who accepted payment agreements with DuPont had not been paid.<ref name="DFP"/>
Several hundred tree owners have filed lawsuits with DuPont. They are seeking [[class action]] status.<ref name="DFP"/>

The '''Institute of Conservation''' ('''Icon''') is a charity and the professional body for [[Conservator-restorer|conservators and restorers]] in the United Kingdom. It has over three thousand members, including [[Conservator-restorer|professional conservators]] working with heritage objects and [[Architectural conservation|buildings]].
==Background== Icon was formed in 2005 as a result of a merger between five smaller bodies: The United Kingdom Institute for Conservation, The Institute of Paper Conservation, The Scottish Society for Conservation and Restoration, the Photographic Materials Conservation Group and the Care of Collections Forum. These five organisations were known collectively as the 'Vanguard Bodies' of the National Council for Conservation-Restoration (NCCR). In 2006 a sixth organisation, the Institute of Conservation Science, which had not been part of the NCCR, merged into Icon.
Seven other bodies which were also members of the NCCR opted not to merge into Icon in 2005. These were: * The British Antique Furniture Restorer's Association<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafra.org.uk|title=Home - British Antique Furniture Restorers' Association|work=British Antique Furniture Restorers' Association}}</ref> * The British Association of Paintings Conservator-Restorers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapcr.org.uk|title=BAPCR Home|work=bapcr.org.uk}}</ref> * Two Irish bodies, the Irish Professional Conservators & Restorers Association (IPCRA) and The Institute for the Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works in Ireland (ICHAWI) - which merged in 2013 into the Institute of Conservators-Restorers in Ireland (ICRI) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icriconservation.ie/about-us/background|title=Home - Institute of Conservator-Restorers in Ireland}}</ref> * Three 'hybrid' bodies, combining conservators and non-conservators in their membership - [[Natural Sciences Collections Association|NatSCA]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.natsca.org/|title=Natural Sciences Collections Association|work=natsca.org}}</ref> the BHI<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bhi.co.uk/|title=British Horological Institute|work=bhi.co.uk}}</ref> and the [[Society of Archivists]] which merged into the [[Archives and Records Association]] in 2010.
==Activities== * Icon is a member of the National Heritage Science Forum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritagescienceforum.org.uk/member-institutions.php|title=National Heritage Science Forum - Home|work=heritagescienceforum.org.uk}}</ref> * Icon operates a professional [[accreditation]] scheme for suitably trained and qualified professionals in [[conservation and restoration]] called PACR (Professional Accreditation of Conservator-Restorers.) * Icon operates the Conservation register<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conservationregister.com|title=The Conservation Register|work=conservationregister.com}}</ref> of practices with an accredited employee in the UK or Ireland * Icon was formerly a member of the [[European Confederation of Conservator-Restorers' Organisations]], but withdrew in 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iiconservation.org/archive/www.iiconservation.org/news/index153d.html?p=106|title=International Conservation News » Blog Archive » Icon withdraws from ECCO|work=iiconservation.org}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official|http://www.icon.org.uk/ }}

'''Jose de Segovia''' ([[Madrid]], 1964) is a Spanish teacher, journalist & theologian.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabino Fernández Campos|title=''Encyclopedia of Spanish Protestantism'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |url=http://www.protestantes.net/enciclopedia.asp?id=637 |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He studied journalism at [[Universidad Complutense]] ([[Madrid]]),<ref>{{cite web |title=''Interview: Introducing Jose De Segovia'' |publisher=Reformation21.org |url=http://www.reformation21.org/blog/2015/03/introducing-jose-de-segovia.php |author=Paul Levy |date=2015-03-13 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> theology at [[Protestant Theological University|University of Kampen]] ([[Netherlands]]) and Bible at The School of Biblical Studies [[Welwyn]] ([[England]]), where he became interested in the work of preacher [[Martyn Lloyd-Jones]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Xavier Memba |url=https://predicalia.wordpress.com/2009/04/02/entrevista-a-jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''Interview: José de Segovia'' |publisher=Predicalia.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> de Segovia is currently leading active student groups such as European Mission Fellowship,<ref>{{cite web|author=Emma Bunting |url=http://europeanmission.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=122:european-huddle&catid=44&Itemid=567 |title=''Introducing José de Segovia by European Missionary Fellowship'' |publisher=Europeanmission.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> [[International Fellowship of Evangelical Students]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Francisco Mira |url=http://www.publicacionesandamio.com/products-page/jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''Introducing José de Segovia by Andamio'' |publisher=Publicacionesandamio.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> and Unión Bíblica.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Vergara |url=http://edificacioncristiana.com/actualidad/articulo1.php |title=''Edificación Cristiana'' |publisher=Edificacioncristiana.com |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He was also President of the Theological Commission on Spanish Evangelical Alliance between 2001 and 2015<ref>{{cite web|author=Evangelina Sierra Bernardino | url=http://www.aeesp.net/pdf/conocenos/memoriaanual/2012/AEE_MEMORIA_2012.pdf |title=''Spanish Evangelical Alliance Dossier, 2012'' |publisher=Aeesp.net |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> and representative of the [[World Evangelical Alliance]] in theological dialogue with the [[Holy See|Vatican]].<ref>{{cite web|author=WEA|title=''Growing Christian Solidarity between Catholics and Evangelicals'' |url=http://www.worldea.org/news/3704/Growing-Christian-Solidarity-between-Catholics-and-Evangelicals |publisher=Worldea.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Joel Forster |title=''Spanish Evangelical Alliance 2015 Meeting'' |publisher=Evangelicalfocus.com|url=http://evangelicalfocus.com/europe/386/A_solid_evangelical_identity_knows_how_to_listen_discourse_and_contend_for_the_faith |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
==Teaching== de Segovia has taught religious studies at the following schools.
* The School of Biblical Studies [[Welwyn]], [[England]] <ref>{{cite web|author=EMF|url=http://europeanmission.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=33 |title=''European Missionary Fellowship'' |publisher=Europeanmission.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Facultad Internacional de Teología [[Castelldefels]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Pedro Sanjaime|url=http://www.ibste.org/profesorado.html |title=''Profesorado'' |publisher=IBSTE |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Centro Evangélico de Estudios Bíblicos [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Pedro Puigvert|url=http://www.ceeb.org.es/cd_00.html |title=''Cuerpo docente'' |publisher=Ceeb.org.es |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Facultad de Teología Protestante [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Roberto Velert|url=http://www.ftuebe.es/depastoral.html |title=''Facultad Protestante de Teología UEBE'' |publisher=Ftuebe.es |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
== Books == Spanish author and historian [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] wrote that "José de Segovia Barrón write theological opinions and culture reviews in the highest professional level, lighting the topics because of its own particular deep perception of life. Reading often his articles it's a pleasure to me, because his own intellectual approach confirms that the Christian thinking does not stunt the brain but, if it's properly used, mind is actually reinforce and encouraged".<ref>{{cite web|author=Cesar Vidal Manzanares |url=http://www.entrelineas.org/contacto.asp |title=''Entrelíneas: Revista de Arte y Fe'' |language=es|publisher=Entrelineas.org |date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
* ''Bob Dylan''. (Andamio, 1985) * ''El protestantismo en España: Pasado, presente y futuro'' (CEM/AMECAN, 1997) * ''Guerra Espiritual: Una reflexión Crítica'' (AEE. Barcelona, 1988) * ''Una fe para el tercer milenio (Peregrino'' Moral de Calatrava, 2002) * ''Entrelíneas: Arte y Fe'' (Consejo Evangélico de Madrid, 2003) Foreword by [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] * ''Ocultismo'' (Andamio. Barcelona, 2004) * ''El príncipe Caspian y la fe de C. S. Lewis'' (Andamio, 2008) * ''Huellas del cristianismo en el cine'' (Consejo Evangélico de Madrid, 2010) * ''El asombro del perdón'' (Andamio, 2010) * ''Center Church Europe'' (Wijnen, Uitgeverij Van, 2014) Co-Author with [[Tim Keller (pastor)]] * ''Evangelio según San Lucas para la Unión Bíblica'' (CLIE, 2016)
== Magazines and digital publications == During the years de Segovia spent at the University (1983-1988) he became interested in Christian thinkers like [[C.S. Lewis]], [[Francis Schaeffer]] and [[José Grau Balcells]], a Spanish writer that he later call his "spiritual father".<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://www.entrelineas.org/leer.asp?a=jose-grau-soli-deo-gloria |language=es|title=''José Grau: Soli Deu Gloria'' |publisher=Entrelineas.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> Historian Gabino Fernández Campos wrote that during these early years, de Segovia was collaborating for Spanish & Dutch magazines like ''Aura'', ''Panorama Evangélico'', ''Adelante'', ''Cuadernos Reforma'', ''Nederlands Dagblad'' or ''Internieuws''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabino Fernández Campos |url=http://www.protestantes.net/enciclopedia.asp?id=637 |language=es|title=''Enciclopedia del Centro de Estudios de la Reforma'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
The following are de Segovia's more popular publications: * ''Entrelíneas''. Printed fanzine including [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] or Luís Alfredo Díaz-Britos. Madrid, 1985.<ref>{{cite web|author=Melisa Panduro Ugaz |url=https://elspleendelosmonos.wordpress.com/2015/05/22/entrevista-a-jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''En el mundo del periodismo de cultura sobran opiniones''. Entrevista a José de Segovia | elspleendelosmonos |publisher=Blog: El Spleen de los monos |date=2015-05-22 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * '"Gospel Club". ''Radio Popular'', 1985 and 1987. * ''Kalos''. Magazine including Jonathan Gelabert. Granollers, 1987. * ''Cultura Pop''. [[RNE Radio 3]], 1987.<ref>{{cite web|author=José Pablo Fernández |url=http://www.protestantes.net/Biblio/Actas/EHP/EHP20e.htm |title=''Encuentro de Historiadores'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Entrelíneas. Online magazine including more than 1000 reviews & podcast since 2002.<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://www.entrelineas.org |title=''Entrelíneas: Revista de Arte y Fe'' |publisher=Entrelineas.org |language=es|date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * ''Radio Encuentro'', including weekly radio interviews since 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sebastián Feliu|url=http://www.radioencuentro.net/index.php/entre-lineas |title=''Entrelíneas'' |publisher=Radio Encuentro |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * ''Evangelical Focus'', including weekly culture reviews since 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://evangelicalfocus.com/l/blogs/709/Between_the_Lines |title=''Between the Lines'' |publisher=Evangelical Focus |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
== Personal life == de Segovia is pastor at Reformed Church in Madrid.<ref>{{cite web|author=José Hutter |url=http://iglesiareformadamadrid.org/?q=about/staff/jos%C3%A9-de-segovia-barr%C3%B3n |title=''Staff Directory | Iglesia Reformada de Madrid'' |language=es|publisher=Iglesiareformadamadrid.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He and his wife Anna have four children.
== References == {{Reflist}}
